Description: Limestone figurine of an individual with a hawk-head holding an offering-tray or perhaps a writing tablet. They are wearing an ankle-length plain tunic, from under which extend the feet.
Curator's comments: Vandelabeele interprets a similar figurine in the Louvre as a scribe holding a writing tablet, related to Horus or Thoth, though she notes that Hermary suggested the individual depicted was wearing a bird-of-prey mask (2009, 127 and fig. 13.6). She also illustrates a similar item said to be from the Karpas peninsular, though was less certain that the individual held a writing tablet. In fact, the Egyptianising kilt and pose of the right arm against the chest - the hand is missing - suggest that this is an example of the well-known variety of male votary in Egyptian dress (see Faegersten 2003). Bibliography: Faegersten, F. 2003, The Egyptianising Male Limestone Statuary from Cyprus. A Study of a Cross-Cultural Eastern Mediterranean Votive Type (Lund: Lund University). Vandelabeele, F. 2009: ‘Representations of Cypriote scribes and carriers of written documents: a link with Egypt?’, in Michaelides et al. 1999, 125-33. in R. Merrillees, D. Michaelides and V.
